data.scenario: My uncle has a terminal illness. When he was 60 he completed an Enduring Power Of Attorney, appointing me as the attorney. He didn't appoint his immediate family as he regarded them as irresponsible financially. Now his mental capacity has deteriorated and it is time to use it.
data.question: Who do I need to tell that I intend to register the EPA?
answers: tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys
• Tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys you intend to register the EPA.

You must tell the first 3 eligible family members from the following list. If there’s no family member in a particular category, move on to the next one. You must try to tell the family members in this order:
• donor’s children (including adopted children but not including stepchildren)
• donor’s brothers and sisters (including half-brothers and half-sisters)
• widow or widower or surviving civil partner of the donor’s child
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s full brothers and sisters)
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s half-brothers and half-sisters)
• donor’s aunts and uncles (full brothers or sisters of a parent of the donor)
• donor’s first cousins (children of the donor’s aunts and uncles who are full brothers and sisters of a parent of the donor)
You must tell all the people in a category if you tell one of them, eg if 1 of the 3 relatives you’re telling is a grandchild and the donor has 15 other grandchildren, you must tell all 16 of them.
If you’re a family member as well as an attorney, you count as one of the people to be told. You’ll still have to tell other people in your category.
evidences: You must register the enduring power of attorney (EPA) as soon as the donor starts to lose mental capacity.
• Tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys you intend to register the EPA.
Download and fill in form EP1PG. Send it to:
• the donor
• at least 3 of the donor’s family members who are eligible - they must be 18 or over and have mental capacity
• any attorneys who were appointed ‘jointly and severally’ but are not applying to register the EPA

You must tell the first 3 eligible family members from the following list. If there’s no family member in a particular category, move on to the next one. You must try to tell the family members in this order:
• donor’s husband, wife or civil partner
• donor’s children (including adopted children but not including stepchildren)
• donor’s parents
• donor’s brothers and sisters (including half-brothers and half-sisters)
• widow or widower or surviving civil partner of the donor’s child
• donor’s grandchildren
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s full brothers and sisters)
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s half-brothers and half-sisters)
• donor’s aunts and uncles (full brothers or sisters of a parent of the donor)
• donor’s first cousins (children of the donor’s aunts and uncles who are full brothers and sisters of a parent of the donor)
You must tell all the people in a category if you tell one of them, eg if 1 of the 3 relatives you’re telling is a grandchild and the donor has 15 other grandchildren, you must tell all 16 of them.
If you’re a family member as well as an attorney, you count as one of the people to be told. You’ll still have to tell other people in your category.

If the person died without making a will and has no living relatives, the Court Funds Office will contact the Treasury Solicitor or Solicitor for the Duchy of Cornwall or Lancaster. They will deal with the person’s money, property and possessions as an unclaimed estate.

Personal Independence Payment (PIP) is a tax-free benefit for people aged 16 or over who have not reached State Pension age. It can help with the extra costs caused by long term ill-health or a disability.
You may be able to get ‘new style’ Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) if you cannot work because of illness or disability.

• an accident at work

data.question: Can I overrule her decision and become her attorney?
evidences: You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).
The person who appointed you is called the ‘donor’ - you are their ‘attorney’.
Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.
You can only use an enduring power of attorney (EPA) if it was made correctly.
Check that the EPA form was:
• made when the donor was at least 18 and had the ability to make their own decisions (they had not lost ‘mental capacity’)
• signed by the donor and a witness who was not one of the attorneys for the EPA
• signed by all the attorneys

• an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
SEN support for children under 5 includes:
• making reasonable adjustments for disabled children, like providing aids like tactile signs
An education, health and care (EHC) plan is for children and young people aged up to 25 who need more support than is available through special educational needs support.
EHC plans identify educational, health and social needs and set out the additional support to meet those needs.

data.question: Am I eligible for Gift Aid?
answers: You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.
• have paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year as you want to claim in Gift Aid
• make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
• that are a payment for goods or services or made because your charity or CASC bought goods and services
• where the donor gets a ‘benefit’ over a certain limit
• from charity cards or of vouchers, for example Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) vouchers
evidences: You can claim back 25p every time an individual donates £1 to your charity or community amateur sports club (CASC). This is called Gift Aid.
You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.
The donor must:
• have paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year as you want to claim in Gift Aid
• make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
You can claim Gift Aid on donations from individuals. The donor must:
• have paid the same amount or more in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year
You cannot claim on donations:
• made through Payroll Giving
• that are a payment for goods or services or made because your charity or CASC bought goods and services
• where the donor gets a ‘benefit’ over a certain limit
• of shares
• from charity cards or of vouchers, for example Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) vouchers

data.scenario: My cousin has difficulties learning things and I generally watch out for him even though he is 24 years old.  He has had problems with a neighbour, who has smashed his windows last night.
data.question: Am I able to take time off work today to help my cousin deal with this issue under the emergency dependent's provisions in this case?
evidences: As an employee you’re allowed time off to deal with an emergency involving a dependant.
A dependant could be a spouse, partner, child, grandchild, parent, or someone who depends on you for care.
You’re allowed a reasonable amount of time off to deal with the emergency, but there’s no set amount of time as it depends on the situation.
You could get time off when a dependant is involved in the following emergencies.
This includes mental or physical illnesses that don’t have to be life-threatening or need full-time care - it could be an existing condition that has worsened.

data.scenario: I am about to give an employee notice for their compulsory redundancy. They have worked for the company for 23 years, and earned £700 per week. The employee will be 43 years old when the notice is given.
data.question: What amount will I need to pay the employee for redundancy?
answers: 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday
a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday
evidences: Employees get:
• 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday
• a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday
• half a week’s pay for each full year of employment up to their 22nd birthday
Length of service is capped at 20 years.
Your employee’s weekly pay is the average they earned per week over the 12 weeks before the day they got their redundancy notice.
Weekly pay is capped at £544. The maximum amount of statutory redundancy pay is £16,320.

evidences: A passenger ship is a ship of any description that carries more than 12 passengers. There are various safety standards for seagoing passenger ships. Local Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) Marine Offices have more information on these standards.
Passenger vessels operating on inland waters - like estuaries, lakes and rivers and canals - must follow safety standards and requirements.
A passenger ship is a vessel that carries more than 12 passengers.

As part of our expansion into the EU, about 5 of our employees will need to be seconded to our office in France for a 6 month period. Their current principal statements make no mention of overseas employment.
data.question: If I make changes to their principal statements, how soon do I need to notify the affected workers?
answers: within one month of making the change
evidences: The written statement is made up of:
• the main document (known as a ‘principal statement’)
Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.
The principal statement must include at least:
• where an employee or worker will be working and whether they might have to relocate
If an employee or worker has to work outside the UK for more than a month, the principal statement must also include:
• how long they’ll be abroad

data.question: Is it ok for the company not holding a consultation?
evidences: If you do not consult employees in a redundancy situation, any redundancies you make will almost certainly be unfair and you could be taken to an employment tribunal.
You must follow ‘collective consultation’ rules if you’re making 20 or more employees redundant within any 90-day period at a single establishment.
Consultation does not have to end in agreement, but it must be carried out with a view to reaching it, including ways of avoiding or reducing the redundancies.

evidences: As the ‘operator’ of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant you must check you meet the general binding rules. You must apply for a permit if you do not.

data.scenario: I rent a room in a house in multiple occupation in Sheffield, England, and have a periodic assured shorthold tenancy agreement with the landlord. Recently, however, he has announced a very large rent increase as part of a "section 13" procedure, to which I and several other tenants in the building strongly object.
data.question: Can we appeal to a housing tribunal over this rent dispute?
answers: • you have an assured or assured shorthold tenancy
evidences: As a tenant, you have the right to:
• challenge excessively high charges
• be protected from unfair eviction and unfair rent
For any tenancy:
• your landlord must get your permission if they want to increase the rent by more than previously agreed
• the rent increase must be fair and realistic, which means in line with average local rents
You can apply to a tribunal to decide on certain rent disputes in England.
You can only apply to the tribunal if:
• you have an assured or assured shorthold tenancy
• your rent’s been increased as part of a ‘section 13 procedure’ - the letter from your landlord will say if it has, and will tell you more about applying to the tribunal

evidences: Gambling operators (for example, betting shops and websites, casinos or slot machine owners) have to pay gambling duties on profits they make from gambling. Customers do not pay duty on their stake (what they bet or pay to play) or winnings.

data.question: What does he need to do to be qualify for the reduced rate?
answers: confirm to your supplier in writing that you meet these conditions
evidences: Your supplier should know about the reduced rate and apply it. You qualify if:
• you’re over 60 when the product is supplied or installed
• the product is installed - you do not get the reduced rate if you just buy it

You’ll need to confirm to your supplier in writing that you meet these conditions. They may give you a form, or you can sign your own declaration. Ask a relative, partner or other responsible person if you’re not able to fill it in yourself.

evidences: You can complain to the Office of the Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) about either:
• bad service you received from an adviser registered with OISC
• immigration advice you received from an unregulated person
There’s a different way to complain about a legal adviser registered with a professional body but not regulated by OISC.
You can complain about:
• poor advice or service
• unreasonable fees
You usually cannot make a complaint about something that happened more than 12 months ago - OISC will decide whether or not to investigate depending on the situation.

data.scenario: A few months ago I bought expensive table saw for my personal use but I want to use it in my business from now. I took a loan to buy it and there are still 10 monthly payments outstanding.
data.question: Can I still use annual investment allowance in this case?
evidences: When you buy business assets you can usually deduct the full value from your profits before tax using annual investment allowance (AIA).
Use writing down allowances instead if:
• the item doesn’t qualify for AIA (for example, cars, gifts or things you owned before you used them in your business)
In most cases, the value is what you paid for the item. Use the market value (the amount you’d expect to sell it for) instead if:
• you owned it before you started using it in your business
For items that are in a single asset pool because you’ve used them outside your business, reduce the amount you can claim by the amount you use them privately.

evidences: Your limited company usually pays Corporation Tax on the profit (‘chargeable gain’) from selling or disposing of an asset.
Assets are things your company owns, such as:

• limited companies
The gain is usually the difference between what you paid for the asset and what you sold it for.

data.scenario: I am a director at the company I work at. Since I have fallen into some financial trouble after my divorce and my house catching on fire I requested a loan from my company. The board agreed and lent me £25000. I have been paying interest on this loan but at a lower rate then the official one since I am still struggling to get on my feet.
data.question: Do we note the payments below the official rate in a normal way?
evidences: Your personal and company tax responsibilities depend on how the loan is settled. You also need to check if you have extra tax responsibilities if:
• the loan was more than £10,000 (£5,000 in 2013-14)
• you paid your company interest on the loan below the official rate
If you’re a shareholder and director, your company must:
• record interest you pay below the official rate as company income
• treat the discounted interest as a ‘benefit in kind’
You must report the interest on a personal Self Assessment tax return. You may have to pay tax on the difference between the official rate and the rate you paid.

evidences: You may be able to get Bereavement Support Payment (BSP) if your husband, wife or civil partner died in the last 21 months.
You must claim within 3 months of your partner’s death to get the full amount. You can claim up to 21 months after their death but you’ll get fewer monthly payments.
You could be eligible if your partner either:
• paid National Insurance contributions for at least 25 weeks in one tax year since 6 April 1975
• died because of an accident at work or a disease caused by work
When they died you must have been:
• under State Pension age

evidences: You could get a Funeral Expenses Payment (also called a Funeral Payment) if you get certain benefits and need help to pay for a funeral you’re arranging.
Funeral Expenses Payment can help pay for some of the costs of the following:
• burial fees for a particular plot
• cremation fees, including the cost of the doctor’s certificate
• travel to arrange or go to the funeral
• the cost of moving the body within the UK, if it’s being moved more than 50 miles
• death certificates or other documents

data.scenario: I have a small business importing wine from France to sell in the London area.
data.question: Will I have to pay duty and VAT on goods that cost around £150?
evidences: Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.
This includes anything new or used that you:
• buy online
• buy abroad and send back to the UK
Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:
• Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).
VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:
• outside the UK to Great Britain
You’ll be charged Customs Duty on all goods sent from outside the UK (or the UK and the EU if you’re in Northern Ireland) if they’re either:
• excise goods
• worth more than £135
You pay Customs Duty on excise goods of any value.
If you’re sent alcohol or tobacco from outside the UK, you’ll be charged Excise Duty at current rates.

data.scenario: I live in England, and a friend wants to send me a ten-pack of cigarettes that we used to smoke together when we lived in Barcelona together. My friend still lives in Barcelona.
data.question: Will I still have to pay Excise Duty even though the cigarettes will be a gift?
evidences: Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.
This includes anything new or used that you:
• receive as a gift
Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:
• Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).
If you’re sent alcohol or tobacco from outside the UK, you’ll be charged Excise Duty at current rates.
It does not matter whether you buy the goods or they’re sent as a gift.

Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:
